docs.snippet: At Los Angeles International Airport, the nation's third busiest after O'Hare in Chicago and Dallas-Fort Worth, tensions and security measures have been high because of terrorism fears. Travel agents also said that a significant number of passenge...
docs.lead_paragraph: At Los Angeles International Airport, the nation's third busiest after O'Hare in Chicago and Dallas-Fort Worth, tensions and security measures have been high because of terrorism fears. Travel agents also said that a significant number of passengers were asking to be booked on flights from smaller suburban airports such as Burbank, Ontario and Long Beach, on the theory that LAX, as Los Angeles International is designated in airline code, was more of a potential target. But airport and airline officials reported few unusual problems, saying that delays caused by tightened security were partly offset by the decline in passenger volume, which is usually very low in January anyway, and the new rules keeping nonpassengers outside security gates.

headline.main: Stepped Up Airport Security: Reports From Abroad and the U.S.
headline.kicker: TRAVEL ADVISORY ON THE GULF CRISIS -- LOS ANGELES

docs.snippet: BELGRADE, April 14 -- The Yugoslav Ministry of Foreign Affairs delivered a circular letter at 6 P.M. today to the United States Embassy and other embassies and missions informing them that the Yugoslav-Greek frontier was off limits to all travel t...
docs.lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, April 14 -- The Yugoslav Ministry of Foreign Affairs delivered a circular letter at 6 P.M. today to the United States Embassy and other embassies and missions informing them that the Yugoslav-Greek frontier was off limits to all travel to a depth of sixty miles.
docs.abstract: Yugoslav bans foreign travel within 60 miles of Greek border; 9-mi limit on other frontiers noted

docs.snippet: Health specialists said a travel ban would do more harm than good because it would isolate impoverished nations that are barely able to cope with the Ebola outbreak....
docs.lead_paragraph: Health specialists said a travel ban would do more harm than good because it would isolate impoverished nations that are barely able to cope with the Ebola outbreak.
docs.abstract: Public health officials say a travel ban on people coming from the three West African nations struggling with Ebola virus outbreak would be ineffective and difficult to carry out and would not entirely prevent people in Ebola-hit countries from entering the United States; health specialists say, that ultimately, a ban would do more harm than good because it would isolate impoverished nations already barely able to cope with virus.

headline.main: Experts Oppose Ebola Travel Ban, Saying It Would Cut Off Worst-Hit Countries
headline.print_headline: Experts Oppose Travel Ban, Saying It Would Cut Off Worst-Hit Countries
